I entered SQQQ, SPXS, SDOW and TZA yesterday after closing out all my energy stocks. Definitely room to the downside of all the indexes. Theyre all oscillating in rising channels, all which break to the downside eventually, but its fairly straightforward to play all the price movement within the channels theyre in. They all break to the downside eventually. Im betting sooner rather than later. I will still sell these bear indexes and buy the triple bull ones if they reverse within the channels in the short term, though.

Mortgage companies dont depend as heavily on interest rates as youd think. They loan out other peoples money, not their own. They dont care if theyre collecting 2 or 8, its free money to them anyway. The lower the interest rate the more money overall they will be able to lend out and the more interest and loan origination fees they can collect. Its better for them to collect 3 off a trillion dollars than 10 off a hundred billion dollars

Some of that money comes in the form of monthly inflows from all the 401Ks out there. Even when the shit hits the proverbial fan like in 2020, people still leave their 401K alone. So every couple of weeks all these passive investors are autobuying lowfee index funds from their paychecks no matter if the market is up or down. Thats why the two biggest shareholders of Apple are Invesco QQQ and Vanguard. That ultimately puts a positive pressure on price, with more weight to the largest companies due to the composition of the ETFs.

Theres too much pressure to print. 2 average per year also means if one year is up 20 the next needs to be 16 to maintain that 2 average but people seem to forget basic math when it comes to inflation.
I should have sold at peak I think it was yesterday morning at 9Am

The Fed isnt wrong, the bond market is bullyIng the Fed into cutting. There are no liquidity issues that would necessitate cuts inline with bond market pricing. Traders want to take advantage of the latest job numbers to make profitable their bond trades, and they will quickly dump back into stocks once they get the excess liquidity they want. Asset prices are still elevated so introducing excess liquidity would be problematic for combating inflation. QE caused wild asset inflation and that changes the dynamic. The Fed needs to get to 2 inflation and holding before it can comfortably cut. We cannot afford loosening monetary policy too early. Fed holds too long and causes a recession, fine. It cuts too soon and allows inflation to gain steam, thats a big problem.
He doing exactly what he wanted

No, actually, Powell wanted to fight asset price inflation, and his policies are just starting to show results. The problem was not just expensive postpandemic hamburgers. The older problem, caused by excessively low interest rates since 2008, was expensive stocks and real estate.

Inflation can be seen as a tax on unproductivity. If you produce something, you just rise the price of that to match. That includes what your charge for your work assuming you are productive. If you dont produce, you lose. That include lenders, renters, etc. Rich people however are not worried by inflation, because by definition it measures the cost of living expenses. Living expenses being a really small part of the typical rich persons income. So the rest of the income goes to investments and usually generates much more than the inflation delta in that period.

Eh, I am not so sure if it actually matters so much in the end. If there is a shortage you can 1 bring in peopel that would work at that price point through migration for example 2 improve working conditions by increasing salary, having less hours etc If you go the second route, generally the process will become more expensive, which could increase the price and lower demand. Or it could make outsourcing seem a lot better option than it was. Or a business might not be able to pay it at all. Or it causes a margin to decrease lower than a margin set in previous years and execs wanting to bring it back in the short term. So much routes through which a business will find a reason to perform actions that bring back their power.

Inflation is always a historical concern for the wealthy. It reduces investment returns those cozy 5 bonds end up with negative actual return for the year when inflation is at 7 and it drives up costs in the job market. If there is anything they hate, its having to pay people more. Who do you think is behind all the bitching about McDonalds paying people 15 hour? Poor people? The rich hate inflation. For working class, if wage gains keep pace with inflation, it can actually be a long term win. The single biggest purchase the noninvestment class ever makes is a home. With a fixed mortgage, if inflation and wages rise 10, its like getting a permanent 10 discount on your single biggest purchase. Now, wages dont always keep pace with inflation so inflation isnt a cure all for the working class but the Fed are taking care of their masters by making sure inflation is prioritized above jobs or overall economic growth.

Long terms swing more with interest rates. Because they offer a longer pay out short terms are expiring soon so there isnt much interest in them. VGLT is one that I like, treasury 20 year, but a lot of people like TLT which is 30 year treasuries. EDV is another 30 year with even more rate sensitivity because they are zero coupon notes but I dont really understand why that is. Then you have TMF, a 3x leveraged longterm treasury bond fund. I bought some of that too. I dont really think a soft landing is possible. I expect a recession before the end of 2025. They will always drop rates fast during a recession to spur the economy. So, TMF seems like a good 1 year play to me.

There are around 38 million people in poverty in the US and around 23 million millionaires. However did you realize that the majority of millionaires in the US are over the age of 50. So the easiest way to pick out someone who isnt a millionaire is to find someone young and working a 95 job. It is surprisingly easy to sort Americans by income and picking a random one that fits either category is also relatively simple. And no, Im not talking about people who dress fashionably or drive a Cybertruck as their daily driver. I mean that old couple that bought their house in the 60s and 70s and have been retried since the 90s. That doesnt change the fact that bottom wages dont keep up with inflation. Middle and high wages do, but bottom wages only change when the minimum wage is adjusted. Of course there are some jobs that are exceptions. Costco workers get inflation based adjustments as do Starbucks employees, but your average Dollar General, Wendys or Walmart employee is not getting inflation adjusted increases. Im not sure why would you think that wages increasing at the top end means that the people at the bottom end are keeping up.

You ASSUMED that I meant that only minimum wage people are poor, but my point is people in poverty work at jobs that have wages that dont increase with inflation. You then responded that America has a lot of millionaires to which I stated America has more people in poverty thank millionaires. You stated that 1.6 of people make minimum wage which is a completely inane and stupid metric to go by especially realizing that if you make 14.75 and minimum wage is 14 then you are making over minimum wages and said you gave references that you NEVER provided, so I instead gave a reference on American poverty directly from the American census which supports the statements I have made. So when did this swap from a conversation about the poorest in the US not getting wage increases that keep up with inflation to only people making minimum wage are poor? Either way Im done arguing with you since you obviously didnt read the census report on poverty and me providing you with any evidence such as the average pay of Walmart or Dollar Tree employees would just be ignored by you.

"Our base case remains for a SOX rebound likely in Q4 as seasonal headwinds dissipate," the analysts wrote.

Which chip stocks are likely to do the best will depend on the performance of the semiconductor sector in general, the bank said. If the SOX does recover in the fourth quarter, BofA recommends the most profitable vendors in their end markets: Nvidia, Broadcom, and KLA.

If volatility continues and demand worsens, the analyst team highlighted names that have traditionally outperformed, including Cadence Design Systems, Synopsys, and Broadcom.

And finally, if there is a powerful resurgence, the most volatile chip stocks, including Arm Holdings, Micron Technology, and On Semiconductor, could be winners, the bank said.
